readable_content:
- Owen Mulhern (2023-12-08): Plastic Straws: Where Are We Now?
The world has turned its attention to the issue of single-use plastic items, particularly plastic straws, since 2018. Organizations such as the European Union (EU) and The United Nations (UN) have been discussing bans or stricter regulations on the use of plastic items.

Back in 2011, 9-year-old Milo Cress initiated the "Be Straw Free" campaign to raise public awareness about unnecessary plastic waste in restaurants. This effort gained attention, and Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper declared July 11 as "Straw Free Day" in 2013 in response. In 2017, the Lonely Whale Foundation launched the "Strawless In Seattle" campaign, resulting in the permanent removal of 2.3 million single-use plastic straws from the city in September. Subsequently, a ban on plastic straws and utensils was enacted in Seattle in July 2018, making it the first major U.S. city to have such a measure.

The movement has gained momentum, with more cities and countries joining in. Future actions on plastic include the European Parliament's approval of the Single-Use Plastics Directive and specific bans on single-use plastics by various countries. This article was written by Winky Leung.
